bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Raymond O. Dart, March 16, 1948

div1.p: Hench informs Dart that he is willing to supply material for the Walter Reed exhibit at the International Congress on Tropical Medicine, in Washington, D.C. However, he is not willing to provide material to the Army Medical Museum as he is using the documents to write his book.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Raymond O. Dart, March 16, 1948
div1.opener:
March 16, 1948
Colonel Raymond O. Dart
Director, Army Institute of Pathology
7th Street and Independence Avenue, S. W.
Washington 25, D. C.
My dear Colonel Dart:
div1.p:
I have your letter of 9 March regarding an exhibit concerning
Walter Reed, to be set up for the International Congress on Tropical Medicine
in Washington in May. Doctor Sawyer has already mentioned such an exhibit
and I shall be glad to cooperate in any way possible. I enclose a carbon
copy which will give you an idea of what is in my collection. I would ap-
preciate it if you would return it to me as this seems to be my only copy.
Please let me know the following: (1) How many exhibit cases on Reed and
his colleagues would you want to have? If you will tell me the limit of
your available exhibiting space, that will help me in suggesting what might
be selected from my material. (2) How long ahead of time must you have the
material? If it is to be exhibited in display cases, no special preparation
is necessary. I can simply bring the material along and spend a couple of
hours setting it up in the display cases and that is what I would rather do.
(3) If thermaterial is to be there the entire time of the Congress, would
it be too late for me to set it up on Tuesday, May 11?

The reason I ask the latter is that a fair amount of this material
is right now on display in cabinets in the University of Virginia Library.
I took it down there in November and it is still there. My plan was to go
to Charlottesville, probably May 10, get the material and come to Washington
and set it up on May 11. If you need more than I have on display in Charlottes-
ville, I will bring it along from here.

It would appear to me that you would in particular want for your
exhibit some of the original fever charts, some of Walter Reed's original
letters, especially the famous New Year's Eve letter and Walter Reed's
special Congressional medal. I also have the original Walter Reed medal awarded
to Mrs. Reed by the American Society of Tropical Medicine. As you will see,
I have certain data concerning Lazear, Agramonte and others.

To satisfy the Latin Americans, you should have certain data con-
cerning Finlay and Delgado and I would suggest that you borrow from the Surgeon
General's Library at least Finlay's original paper, possibly three or four of
his later papers. You could exhibit photographs of some of the Finlay busts.
I have copies of several of these. You should have a photograph of Finlay.
Wouldn't it be an excellent idea to have on display Cornwell's original
painting, “Conquerors of Yellow Fever”. I enclose a reproduction of it. It
was painted for Wyeth, Incorporated, and Mr. Frank Law, Vice President of
Wyeth, Incorporated, 1600 Arch Street, Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, will be
the man to contact regarding this. That has become a rather well-known
painting and I should think its demonstration at the exhibit would be most

Colonel Raymond O. Dart

appropriate. If the original painting is not available, a colored reproduc-
tion about three times the size of the one in my reprint is available for
display.

If you will let me know as soon as possible about what you want,
I will start collecting it and some of it will have to be photographed for
the program to be used at the unveiling of the Walter Reed bust in the Hall
of Fame, May 20.

I regret that I cannot accept your invitation to contribute any
of this material to the permanent collection of the Army Medical Museum as
I am utilizing all of this material in the publication of a book which is in
preparation and which will take some time to finish. Indeed my collection is
so extensive that the Mayo Foundation is considering setting aside a special
museum room for it in the new clinic building to be built in the near future.
Incidentally, you might borrow from the Archives the few fever charts which
they have. I believe they have that of Private Dean and also one for Carroll
and Lazear.
div1.closer:
Sincerely yours, P. S. Hench, M. D. PSH:alc
P. S.: Can you help me out in one matter. I just returned yesterday from
Cuba. I am writing a book on the Conquest of Yellow Fever considering all
angles, the work of Finlay as well as that of the American Commission. I
have a copy of “The Collective Works of Dr. Carlos J. Finlay” but this con-
tains only a very few translations into English of his Spanish articles. In
Cuba last week, I visited the National Academy of Sciences, the Finlay Insti-
tute and the surviving son of Finlay and other people, asking if any of them
had English translations of all of Finlay's papers. They did not. It occurs
to me that Reed and His colleagues certainly must have had English translations
of all of these articles as I don't believe Carroll or Lazear read Spanish.
Could you find out for me whether your Institute or whether the Surgeon General's
Library has such translations. I am most anxious to have them.
